oai_dc:dc.dc:title: MODELING CORAL REEF RESTORATION TO REDUCE COASTAL HAZARDS FROM SCALES OF CENTIMETERS TO KILOMETERS
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Storlazzi, Curt
Norris, Ben
Pomeroy, Andrew
Roelvink, Floortje
Dongeren, Ap van
Reguero, Borja
Beck, Michael
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Coral reefs are effective natural barriers that protect adjacent coastal communities from hazards such as erosion and storm-induced flooding. However, the degradation of coral reefs compromises their efficacy to protect against these hazards, making degraded reefs a target for restoration. At present, there is little guidance on how and where to restore coral reefs for coastal hazard risk reduction. Here we present modeling at a series of scales to provide such guidance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 37 (2022): Proceedings of 37th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Sydney, Australia, 2022; management.3
